conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the normal force F_N between the locking tongue D and the locking groove E when the door is in the self-locking state.
Identify the forces acting on the locking tongue D: spring force F_s, weight mg, normal force F_N, and frictional force F_f.
Spring force F_s is given by Hooke's law: F_s = kx.
Weight of the locking tongue D is mg.
Normal force F_N is perpendicular to the surface of the locking groove E.
Frictional force F_f is parallel to the surface of the locking groove E and acts opposite to sliding motion.
Spring force F_s can be resolved into parallel component F_{s\parallel} = kx \sin \theta.
Spring force F_s can be resolved into perpendicular component F_{s\perp} = kx \cos \theta.
Weight of locking tongue D can be resolved into parallel component F_{g\parallel} = mg \sin \theta.
Weight of locking tongue D can be resolved into perpendicular component F_{g\perp} = mg \cos \theta.
Normal force F_N is the sum of perpendicular components: F_N = (kx + mg) \cos \theta.
Maximum static friction force F_{fm} is given by F_{fm} = \mu F_N.
For self-locking, sum of parallel components must be greater than or equal to maximum static friction force: kx \sin \theta + mg \sin \theta \geq \mu (kx \cos \theta + mg \cos \theta).
Factor out common terms: \sin \theta (kx + mg) \geq \mu \cos \theta (kx + mg).
Normal force F_N is: F_N = (kx + mg) \cos \theta.
